channel.title: Last Day - NEW & UPDATE
channel.description: All NEW and UPDATE articles from the last day with enhanced metadata

item.title: NEW: SLSH Alliance Hits 100+ Firms in Sophisticated Okta SSO Voice Phishing Blitz
item.description:
Headline: SLSH Alliance Hits 100+ Firms in Sophisticated Okta SSO Voice Phishing Blitz

Summary:
A highly organized, human-led phishing campaign is targeting the Okta Single Sign-On (SSO) credentials of over 100 high-profile enterprises across technology, finance, and healthcare. The attack, attributed to the SLSH cybercrime alliance (linked to Scattered Spider and ShinyHunters), uses interactive voice phishing (vishing) to manipulate victims into approving multi-factor authentication (MFA) prompts. The attackers employ a live phishing panel to intercept credentials and MFA tokens in real-time, enabling them to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to corporate networks. The widespread campaign has prepared infrastructure to target major companies like Atlassian, Moderna, Zillow, and Halliburton, posing a significant identity-based threat.

Severity: High

Categories: Phishing, Threat Actor, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Analysis of a large-scale, human-led phishing campaign by the SLSH cybercrime group targeting Okta SSO credentials at over 100 enterprises using voice phishing to bypass MFA.

Article Slug: shinyhunters-linked-group-targets-100-plus-firms-in-okta-sso-phishing-campaign

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CRITICAL: Ivanti Patches Two Actively Exploited RCE Zero-Days in EPMM
item.description:
Headline: CRITICAL: Ivanti Patches Two Actively Exploited RCE Zero-Days in EPMM

Summary:
Ivanti has released urgent security patches for two critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities, CVE-2026-1281 and CVE-2026-1340, affecting its Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) solution, formerly MobileIron Core. Both flaws are rated 9.8 out of 10 on the CVSS scale and are confirmed to be actively exploited in the wild as zero-days. An unauthenticated attacker can exploit these vulnerabilities to execute arbitrary code on an affected appliance, granting them access to sensitive mobile device management data. Given the active exploitation, administrators are urged to apply the temporary RPM script patches immediately while awaiting a permanent fix in the upcoming version 12.8.0.0.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Urgent security alert: Ivanti has patched two critical, actively exploited RCE zero-day vulnerabilities (CVE-2026-1281, CVE-2026-1340) in its EPMM product. Immediate patching is required.

Article Slug: ivanti-patches-two-critical-actively-exploited-rce-flaws-in-epmm

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Sandworm Unleashes New 'DynoWiper' Malware in Destructive Attack on Polish Energy Sector
item.description:
Headline: Sandworm Unleashes New 'DynoWiper' Malware in Destructive Attack on Polish Energy Sector

Summary:
The Russia-aligned threat actor Sandworm is believed to be behind a destructive cyberattack that targeted an energy company in Poland in late 2025. Researchers from ESET analyzed the new data-wiping malware, dubbed 'DynoWiper,' and attributed the attack to Sandworm with medium confidence. The TTPs observed in the incident closely mirror those from a previous attack using the ZOV wiper against targets in Ukraine. The attack was reportedly thwarted by an EDR/XDR solution that blocked the wiper's execution, limiting the damage. This event marks a significant escalation, representing a rare deployment of destructive malware by a Russia-aligned group against Poland's critical energy infrastructure.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Malware, Threat Actor, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Analysis of the DynoWiper malware deployed by the Sandworm threat actor in a destructive cyberattack against an energy company in Poland, highlighting the threat to critical infrastructure.

Article Slug: sandworm-deploys-dynowiper-malware-in-attack-on-polish-energy-sector

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Software Supply Chain Under Siege: 450,000+ Malicious Packages Hit Open-Source in 2025
item.description:
Headline: Software Supply Chain Under Siege: 450,000+ Malicious Packages Hit Open-Source in 2025

Summary:
A new report from Sonatype reveals a massive surge in software supply chain attacks, with over 450,000 new malicious open-source components discovered in 2025. The attacks show a strategic shift, with threat actors focusing their efforts on executing code directly within developer environments and CI/CD pipelines, rather than targeting end-users. The npm registry was the primary battleground for these automated, high-volume campaigns, which often involved publishing large batches of similarly named malicious packages. These packages would frequently reappear shortly after being removed, highlighting the persistent and automated nature of the threat to the software development lifecycle.

Severity: High

Categories: Supply Chain Attack, Malware, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Analysis

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: A report from Sonatype details how over 450,000 malicious open-source packages were used in 2025 to target developer environments and CI/CD pipelines, primarily via the npm registry.

Article Slug: report-450000-malicious-open-source-packages-targeted-developers-in-2025

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: DDoS Chaos: Kimwolf, Aisuru, and Mirai Botnets Fuel Surge in Automated Attacks
item.description:
Headline: DDoS Chaos: Kimwolf, Aisuru, and Mirai Botnets Fuel Surge in Automated Attacks

Summary:
Security researchers are observing a significant increase in highly automated Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, powered by three major botnets: Kimwolf, Aisuru, and new variants of the notorious Mirai botnet. These campaigns leverage adaptive attack patterns and are fueled by the mass exploitation of insecure Internet of Things (IoT) devices. Attackers are particularly targeting consumer-grade gadgets, including unauthorized Android TV streaming boxes, which often have weak default credentials and outdated firmware. The global supply chain for these low-cost devices is creating a vast and easily exploitable pool of resources for botnet operators, posing a continuous threat to online service availability.

Severity: High

Categories: Cyberattack, IoT Security, Malware

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Analysis of the surge in automated DDoS attacks driven by the Kimwolf, Aisuru, and Mirai botnets, which exploit insecure IoT devices and Android TV streaming boxes.

Article Slug: surge-in-ddos-attacks-driven-by-kimwolf-aisuru-and-mirai-botnets

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Microsoft Patches Actively Exploited Office Zero-Day Flaw Added to CISA's KEV List
item.description:
Headline: Microsoft Patches Actively Exploited Office Zero-Day Flaw Added to CISA's KEV List

Summary:
Microsoft has released an out-of-band security update for an 'Important' security feature bypass vulnerability, CVE-2026-21509, in Microsoft Office. The flaw, which has a CVSS score of 7.8, is being actively exploited in the wild and allows an attacker to bypass Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) mitigations by tricking a user into opening a malicious file. This could expose users to vulnerable COM/OLE controls. In response to the active exploitation, CISA has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating patching for federal agencies. The vulnerability affects a wide range of products, including Microsoft 365 Apps and perpetual versions like Office 2019 and LTSC 2021.

Severity: High

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Microsoft has patched CVE-2026-21509, an actively exploited security feature bypass vulnerability in Microsoft Office. CISA has added the flaw to its KEV catalog, urging immediate updates.

Article Slug: microsoft-patches-actively-exploited-office-zero-day-cve-2026-21509

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Novel Phishing Attack Abuses Vercel and Telegram to Deliver RATs
item.description:
Headline: Novel Phishing Attack Abuses Vercel and Telegram to Deliver RATs

Summary:
A novel phishing campaign, observed between November 2025 and January 2026, is abusing trusted `*.vercel.app` domains to bypass email security filters and deliver malware. The attack, detailed by Cloudflare, uses financial lures like fake invoices to trick victims into clicking. A unique feature is its Telegram-gated payload delivery, which requires interaction with a Telegram bot to receive the final payload. This technique effectively filters out automated sandboxes and security researchers, ensuring the malware is only delivered to genuine targets. The campaign's ultimate goal is to install GoTo Resolve, a legitimate remote access tool, which is then abused by attackers for persistent access and control.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Phishing, Malware, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A new phishing campaign abuses Vercel domains and a Telegram-gated delivery mechanism to evade security and install the GoTo Resolve remote access tool for malicious use.

Article Slug: phishing-campaign-uses-vercel-domains-and-telegram-to-deliver-rat

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Releases Roadmap for Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) Migration
item.description:
Headline: CISA Releases Roadmap for Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) Migration

Summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has released initial guidance to help federal agencies and other organizations prepare for the transition to post-quantum cryptography (PQC). The document includes a list of hardware and software product categories that are expected to support the new quantum-resistant cryptographic standards. The guidance is a key part of the U.S. government's strategy to harden digital infrastructure against the future threat of quantum computers, which will be capable of breaking current public-key cryptography. The roadmap covers areas like cloud services, endpoint security, and networking hardware, aiming to streamline the complex migration process.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Regulatory, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: CISA has published guidance and a product roadmap to help federal agencies and other organizations prepare for the migration to post-quantum cryptography (PQC) standards.

Article Slug: cisa-publishes-guidance-to-aid-federal-agencies-in-pqc-migration

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: New 'Sicarii Ransomware' RaaS Emerges, Targeting U.S. Manufacturing
item.description:
Headline: New 'Sicarii Ransomware' RaaS Emerges, Targeting U.S. Manufacturing

Summary:
A new ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation named 'Sicarii Ransomware' has been discovered by researchers at CYFIRMA. Active since late 2025, the group is targeting the manufacturing sector in the United States. The malware encrypts victim files using AES-GCM and appends a '.sicarii' extension to them. In addition to encryption, the malware is capable of collecting system information and credentials from infected hosts, suggesting a double-extortion tactic may be part of their playbook. Tactical recommendations to defend against this threat include enhanced monitoring, maintaining offline backups, and strengthening network segmentation.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Threat Actor, Malware

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A new ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group named Sicarii Ransomware is targeting the U.S. manufacturing sector, using AES-GCM encryption and double-extortion tactics.

Article Slug: new-sicarii-ransomware-raas-operation-identified-in-the-wild

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Industry Responds to Threats with New Tools for Supply Chain, AI, and Malware Analysis
item.description:
Headline: Industry Responds to Threats with New Tools for Supply Chain, AI, and Malware Analysis

Summary:
In response to the evolving threat landscape, several cybersecurity firms have launched new products in January 2026. SpyCloud has released its Supply Chain Threat Protection solution to address identity threats within vendor ecosystems. Vectra AI has enhanced its platform to specifically counter attacks that leverage AI, focusing on the AI attack lifecycle. Additionally, Booz Allen Hamilton has made its Vellox Reverser tool generally available, aiming to accelerate malware reverse engineering and threat intelligence analysis for cyber defenders. These releases highlight key areas of focus for the industry: securing the supply chain, defending against AI-powered threats, and speeding up incident analysis.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Security Operations, Supply Chain Attack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: An overview of new cybersecurity products released in January 2026, including SpyCloud's Supply Chain Threat Protection, Vectra AI's platform updates, and Booz Allen's Vellox Reverser.

Article Slug: security-vendors-launch-new-products-for-supply-chain-ai-and-malware-analysis

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Global Phishing Campaign Lures Victims with Fake Job Offers
item.description:
Headline: Global Phishing Campaign Lures Victims with Fake Job Offers

Summary:
A multi-lingual phishing campaign is targeting job seekers across the United States, United Kingdom, France, Italy, and Spain. According to research from Bitdefender, attackers are impersonating well-known employers and staffing companies, sending emails with fake job offers that promise easy work and fast interviews. The messages are tailored to the recipient's language and location. When a victim clicks a link in the email, they are taken to a credential harvesting webpage designed to steal personal data and login information. This campaign capitalizes on social engineering tactics that prey on individuals' career aspirations.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Phishing

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: A widespread, multi-lingual phishing campaign is impersonating employers with fake job offers to steal credentials and personal data from job seekers in several countries.

Article Slug: widespread-phishing-campaign-uses-fake-job-offers-to-steal-credentials

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Apple Boosts Privacy in iOS 26.3 with 'Limit Precise Location' Feature
item.description:
Headline: Apple Boosts Privacy in iOS 26.3 with 'Limit Precise Location' Feature

Summary:
Apple has introduced a new privacy feature called 'limit precise location' in its iOS 26.3 update. This setting is designed to give users more control over their data by reducing the precision of location information shared with cellular networks. While carriers still receive location data for operational purposes, the feature prevents them from obtaining a user's exact, fine-grained location, making it more difficult to track their precise movements. This update is part of a broader industry trend toward providing users with more granular privacy controls and addressing concerns about location tracking by mobile carriers.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Mobile Security, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 3 minutes

Meta Description: Apple's iOS 26.3 update includes a new 'limit precise location' privacy setting, which reduces the precision of location data shared with cellular networks to enhance user privacy.

Article Slug: apple-enhances-location-privacy-in-ios-26-3-update

Published Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 30 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Microsoft Office Zero-Day Under Active Attack Bypasses Security Features
item.description:
Headline: Microsoft Office Zero-Day Under Active Attack Bypasses Security Features

Summary:
Microsoft has issued an emergency out-of-band patch for a high-severity zero-day vulnerability in Microsoft Office, CVE-2026-21509. The flaw, a security feature bypass with a CVSS score of 7.8, is being actively exploited in the wild through malicious documents. It allows attackers to circumvent Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) protections, leading to code execution if a user opens a specially crafted file. The vulnerability affects a wide range of Office products, including Office 2016 through LTSC 2024 and Microsoft 365 Apps. CISA has added the flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating urgent patching for federal agencies and signaling a significant risk to all organizations.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Microsoft releases an emergency patch for CVE-2026-21509, a high-severity zero-day vulnerability in Microsoft Office being actively exploited to bypass security features. Learn about the impact and how to mitigate.

Article Slug: microsoft-office-zero-day-cve-2026-21509-actively-exploited

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Critical FortiCloud SSO Flaw Under Active Attack, CISA Issues Urgent Warning
item.description:
Headline: Critical FortiCloud SSO Flaw Under Active Attack, CISA Issues Urgent Warning

Summary:
A critical authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2026-24858, in Fortinet's FortiCloud single sign-on (SSO) service is under active exploitation. The flaw allows an attacker with a registered FortiCloud account to gain unauthorized access to devices belonging to other accounts. Fortinet has observed malicious activity, including unauthorized configuration changes and account creation on FortiGate devices. CISA has added the vulnerability to its KEV catalog, urging immediate action. Fortinet temporarily disabled the SSO service to implement mitigations and is working on permanent patches for affected products like FortiOS, FortiManager, and FortiWeb.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Cyberattack, Cloud Security

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: An actively exploited critical authentication bypass vulnerability (CVE-2026-24858) in Fortinet's FortiCloud SSO allows attackers to control devices. CISA has issued a warning. Learn the impact and mitigation steps.

Article Slug: fortinet-forticloud-sso-flaw-cve-2026-24858-actively-exploited

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: ShinyHunters Claims Cyberattacks on Bumble, Panera, Match, and Crunchbase
item.description:
Headline: ShinyHunters Claims Cyberattacks on Bumble, Panera, Match, and Crunchbase

Summary:
Several high-profile US companies, including Bumble, Panera Bread, Match Group, and Crunchbase, have been targeted in a series of cyberattacks. A group calling itself 'ShinyHunters' has claimed responsibility, with evidence pointing towards a coordinated social engineering campaign. The impact varies across the companies: Bumble reported a contractor's account was phished, leading to brief network access but no user data compromise. Match Group confirmed a limited amount of user data was affected, while Panera and Crunchbase also reported incidents involving contact information and corporate documents, respectively. The attacks highlight a trend towards leveraging compromised contact data for further malicious activities.

Severity: High

Categories: Cyberattack, Data Breach, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A wave of cyberattacks claimed by ShinyHunters has hit Bumble, Panera Bread, Match Group, and Crunchbase, stemming from a social engineering campaign. Learn about the impact and how to defend against such threats.

Article Slug: shinyhunters-claims-attacks-on-bumble-panera-match-crunchbase

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Fake Python Spellchecker Packages on PyPI Deploy Remote Access Trojan
item.description:
Headline: Fake Python Spellchecker Packages on PyPI Deploy Remote Access Trojan

Summary:
Two malicious packages, `spellcheckerpy` and `spellcheckpy`, were discovered and removed from the Python Package Index (PyPI). Masquerading as legitimate spell-checking utilities, these packages were downloaded over 1,000 times and were designed to install a full-featured remote access trojan (RAT) on developers' systems. The attacker used a novel technique, hiding a Base64-encoded payload within a Basque language dictionary file (`eu.json.gz`) and activating it only in a later version of the package. This supply chain attack highlights the growing threat of malware in open-source repositories.

Severity: High

Categories: Malware, Supply Chain Attack, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Researchers discovered two malicious Python packages on PyPI, 'spellcheckerpy' and 'spellcheckpy', that delivered a remote access trojan (RAT) using a novel hiding technique. Learn about this supply chain attack.

Article Slug: malicious-python-spellchecker-packages-on-pypi-deliver-rat

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Critical 1-Click RCE Flaw in IDIS Cloud Manager Puts Users at Risk
item.description:
Headline: Critical 1-Click RCE Flaw in IDIS Cloud Manager Puts Users at Risk

Summary:
A critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability, CVE-2025-12556, has been discovered in the IDIS Cloud Manager (ICM) viewer by researchers at Claroty's Team82. The flaw, which has a CVSS v4 score of 8.7, allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on a user's machine by convincing them to click a specially crafted link. This '1-click RCE' vulnerability bypasses the browser sandbox, making it a potent weapon for spear-phishing campaigns. IDIS has released version 1.7.1 to address the issue and urges users to upgrade or uninstall the software immediately.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Phishing, Industrial Control Systems

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: Claroty Team82 discovers a critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability (CVE-2025-12556) in the IDIS Cloud Manager viewer, allowing attackers to compromise systems with a single click. Update to version 1.7.1 now.

Article Slug: critical-rce-flaw-cve-2025-12556-in-idis-cloud-manager-viewer

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Illinois Department of Human Services Breach Exposes Data of 700,000
item.description:
Headline: Illinois Department of Human Services Breach Exposes Data of 700,000

Summary:
The Illinois Department of Human Services (IDHS) has disclosed a massive data breach that exposed the sensitive records of approximately 700,000 state residents. The incident, one of the largest public-sector breaches of 2026, impacted recipients of various state aid programs. Exposed data for over 672,000 Medicaid and Medicare Savings Program recipients includes addresses, case numbers, and medical plan names. A separate set of 32,000 records belonging to customers of the Division of Rehabilitation Services was also compromised, exposing names, addresses, and case details. The investigation is ongoing to determine the cause and full scope of the breach.

Severity: High

Categories: Data Breach, Regulatory, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The Illinois Department of Human Services (IDHS) has confirmed a massive data breach affecting 700,000 people, exposing sensitive PII and PHI from Medicaid and other programs. Learn about the impact of this major public-sector breach.

Article Slug: illinois-dhs-data-breach-exposes-700k-records

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: AI-Fueled Cyberattacks Surge by 70%, Check Point's 2026 Report Reveals
item.description:
Headline: AI-Fueled Cyberattacks Surge by 70%, Check Point's 2026 Report Reveals

Summary:
Check Point's 14th annual Cyber Security Report highlights a dramatic escalation in the global threat landscape, revealing a 70% increase in cyberattacks since 2023. The 2026 report, analyzing trends from 2025, found that organizations faced an average of 1,968 attacks per week. A primary driver of this surge is the weaponization of Artificial Intelligence (AI), which attackers are using to enhance social engineering, accelerate malware development, and automate reconnaissance. The report also notes a shift in ransomware tactics towards data-only extortion and an increase in attacks targeting network edge devices like VPNs and IoT.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Ransomware, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Check Point's 2026 Cyber Security Report shows a 70% increase in global cyberattacks, fueled by attackers' use of AI. Learn about the key trends in ransomware, edge device security, and how to adapt your defense strategy.

Article Slug: check-point-2026-cyber-security-report-ai-drives-attack-surge

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Canada's Cyber Security Centre Warns of AI-Fueled Ransomware Evolution
item.description:
Headline: Canada's Cyber Security Centre Warns of AI-Fueled Ransomware Evolution

Summary:
The Canadian Centre for Cyber Security has issued a new 'Ransomware Threat Outlook,' warning that the ransomware threat to Canadian organizations is growing and evolving rapidly. The report highlights that criminals are increasingly leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to make their attacks more sophisticated, easier to execute, and harder to detect. A key trend identified is the shift towards 'multi-extortion' tactics, where attackers steal data and threaten to leak it in addition to encrypting it. The report stresses that despite the advanced tactics, strong cyber hygiene remains a primary defense.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Ransomware, Regulatory

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The Canadian Centre for Cyber Security's latest report warns that criminals are using AI to fuel more sophisticated ransomware and multi-extortion attacks against Canadian organizations. Learn about the evolving threat.

Article Slug: canadian-cyber-centre-warns-of-ai-fueled-ransomware-threat

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

item.title: NEW: Clop Ransomware Group Claims Attack on Canadian Helicopter Company
item.description:
Headline: Clop Ransomware Group Claims Attack on Canadian Helicopter Company

Summary:
The notorious Clop ransomware group has claimed responsibility for a cyberattack against CMHHELI.COM, a Canadian company. On January 29, 2026, the group added the company to its dark web leak site, threatening to publish stolen data if a ransom is not paid. This incident highlights the persistent and indiscriminate nature of major ransomware gangs, who continue to target organizations of all sizes. Security experts advise victims to initiate incident response, validate backups, and engage professionals before considering any communication with the attackers.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Threat Actor, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The Clop ransomware gang has listed Canadian company CMHHELI.COM as a victim on its data leak site, threatening to release stolen data in a double-extortion attack. Learn about the Clop threat actor and mitigation strategies.

Article Slug: clop-ransomware-claims-attack-on-canadian-company-cmhheli

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

item.title: NEW: Open-Source Malware Skyrockets by 75%, Sonatype's 2026 Report Warns
item.description:
Headline: Open-Source Malware Skyrockets by 75%, Sonatype's 2026 Report Warns

Summary:
Sonatype's 2026 'State of the Software Supply Chain' report reveals an alarming 75% increase in malicious open-source packages, with over 1.233 million identified. The report connects this surge to the rapid adoption of AI and automation in software development, which has accelerated open-source consumption to 9.8 trillion downloads across major registries. This increased velocity expands the attack surface, making it easier for attackers to inject malware into the software supply chain. The report also notes that 86% of traffic from Maven Central, a key Java repository, now comes from automated cloud services, amplifying the risk of widespread compromise from a single malicious package.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Supply Chain Attack, Threat Intelligence, Malware

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Discover the findings of Sonatype's 2026 State of the Software Supply Chain report, which reveals a 75% increase in open-source malware, driven by AI and automation in software development.

Article Slug: sonatype-2026-report-open-source-malware-surges-75-percent

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

item.title: NEW: Convergence of Identity and Data Security Creates New Attack Vectors, Netwrix Warns
item.description:
Headline: Convergence of Identity and Data Security Creates New Attack Vectors, Netwrix Warns

Summary:
A new report from Netwrix warns that the next wave of cyber threats will arise from the convergence of identity and data security. As organizations increasingly rely on automated workflows to manage data access, attackers are shifting their focus from stealing individual credentials to exploiting misconfigured identity orchestration and automation. The report predicts that failures in identity automation will directly lead to data exposure. With the rise of agentic AI, which can autonomously perform actions, securing the identity of these non-human agents becomes paramount. Netwrix concludes that unified visibility across both identity management and data security is now essential to mitigate these emerging risks.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Policy and Compliance, Cloud Security

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A new report from Netwrix warns that attackers are shifting focus to exploit the convergence of identity and data security, targeting automation and orchestration workflows. Learn about the emerging risks from this trend and AI.

Article Slug: netwrix-report-identity-and-data-security-convergence-threats

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 15:00:00 GMT

item.title: NEW: SoundCloud Breach Exposes Private Emails of 29.8 Million Users
item.description:
Headline: SoundCloud Breach Exposes Private Emails of 29.8 Million Users

Summary:
A significant data breach at the music streaming service SoundCloud has resulted in the public release of a database containing the personal details of 29.8 million users. The data was leaked in January 2026 after the company reportedly refused to pay a ransom demand. The primary risk from this breach stems from the linking of users' private email addresses with their public profile metadata. This combination provides a rich source of data for attackers to launch targeted phishing, credential stuffing, and social engineering campaigns. The breach has been indexed by the notification service HaveIBeenPwned.

Severity: High

Categories: Data Breach, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A massive data breach at SoundCloud has publicly exposed a database with the private email addresses and profile data of 29.8 million users. Learn about the risks and how affected users can protect themselves.

Article Slug: soundcloud-data-breach-exposes-29-million-users

Published Date: Thu, 29 Jan 2026 00:00:00 GMT

item.title: UPDATE: ShinyHunters Claims Breach of Crunchbase, Betterment via Okta Vishing Attacks
item.description:
Headline: ShinyHunters Claims Breach of Crunchbase, Betterment via Okta Vishing Attacks

Summary:
The notorious cyber extortion syndicate ShinyHunters has claimed responsibility for breaching business intelligence firm Crunchbase and financial advisory company Betterment. According to the threat actor, the initial access was gained by using sophisticated voice phishing (vishing) attacks to socially engineer employees and compromise their Okta single sign-on (SSO) credentials. This method allows attackers to bypass weaker forms of multi-factor authentication. Neither of the targeted companies has publicly confirmed the breach.

Severity: High

Categories: Phishing, Data Breach, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The ShinyHunters extortion group has claimed responsibility for breaching Crunchbase and Betterment by using voice phishing (vishing) to defeat Okta single sign-on (SSO) security.

Article Slug: shinyhunters-claims-breaches-of-crunchbase-betterment-via-okta-vishing
